questions.text: A new screening test for detecting cervical cancer is being studied in a group of 100 women.  60 women tested negative and 40 tested positive.  Among the women who were tested positive by the new test 30 were actually positive and among the women who tested negative, 10 were having the disease. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value is 75%

The data given in the question is tabulated as follows:

  Diseased Not diseased Total
Test positive 30 (TP) 10 (FP) 40
Test negative 10 (FN) 50 (TN) 60
Total 40 60 100

TP - True positive, FP - False positive, FN - False negative, TN - True negative.

Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

Here PPV = 30/(30+10) x 100 = 30/40 x 100 = 75%

Predictive value of a positive test:

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease. Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. It is highly related to the prevalence of a disease. The predictive value of a positive test will be more accurate if the disease is more prevalent and vice-versa.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.

TP + FN
Specificity      TN

Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP

Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN

  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: What is the earliest sign seen on cystoscopy in a patient suspected to have bladder tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.

In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced (thimble bladder). This is managed by augmentation cystoplasty.

The following X-ray KUB shows a thimble bladder:


Ureteric lesions can also be seen in genitourinary tuberculosis. They include:

  • Kerr’s kink - kinking of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ)
  • Ureteral stricture
  • Beaded ureter
  • Shortening of the ureter
  • Golf hole ureter - Longitudinal fibrosis leading to shortening of the ureter and pulling up the orifice as a gaping hole. Reimplantation of ureter is done.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 3 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presenting with halitosis and regurgitation, underwent a barium swallow scan as shown below. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the suspected condition​?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient with halitosis and regurgitation with the GIF of an X-ray showing the barium swallow filling a sac in the posterior pharyngeal wall is highly suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian's dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus and the lower cricopharyngeus. The cricopharyngeus muscle is divisible into the superficial oblique component (pars oblique) and the deeper transverse component (pars fundiformis). These 2 components of the muscle have a potential space between them termed Killian's dehiscence.  

As a result of the uncoordinated contraction between the cricopharyngeus and upper oesophagal sphincter, mucosal herniation through the Killian's dehiscence gives rise to Zenker's diverticulum. This diverticulum is a common site for food impaction and accumulation (halitosis, regurgitation) and may cause dysphagia in affected patients. 

Note - Another potential site of diverticulum formation is the Laimer's triangle, situated below the cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal fibres of the oesophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the hanging mark is false?

choices.text: The most common position of the knot is under the chin
The gap in the hanging mark indicates the point of suspension
The hanging mark is situated above the thyroid cartilage
The mark dries to a parchment like consistency post-mortem

questions.solution:
The knot in a suicidal hanging is much less likely to be found under the chin than in other positions - behind the ear or at the occiput.

Hanging mark

  • The hanging mark almost never completely encircles the neck unless a slipknot is used.
  • In most instances the point of suspension is indicated by a gap in the skin mark.
  • This gap is usually seen at one or other side of the neck or at the centre of the back of the neck. Much less often it is under the chin.
  • The hanging mark is situated higher on the neck than in strangulation, usually being directly under the chin anteriorly, passing round beneath the jawbones and rising at the sides or back of the neck to the usual gap under the knot.
  • The mark may be abraded, brown and dried to a parchment-like consistency after death.
  • There may be a narrow red zone either above or below (or both sides) the ligature mark. This is not an indicator of vital reaction but is due to the displacement of blood laterally from under the zone of maximum pressure.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is nodular acne and the drug of choice for this condition is oral isotretinoin.

Isotretinoin is an orally administered systemic retinoid that is used in the management of severe acne.

Commonly seen adverse effects of isotretinoin are cheilitis (dry lips), xerosis (dry skin), xerostomia (dry mouth), dry nose, and increased sun sensitivity. 

Oral isotretinoin is contraindicated in pregnant patients and patients who may be pregnant. 

Other Options:

Option A: Steroids are not indicated in cases of acne as they can exacerbate the condition due to increased sebum production and skin cell turnover disruption.

Options B and C: Nodulocystic acne is a severe form of acne that often requires more aggressive treatment options, such as isotretinoin. While antibiotics may be used in some cases of nodulocystic acne, they are not the first-line treatment option.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker who is diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents to the ER with complaints of nausea, confusion,  and dizziness. After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). The SIADH is characterized by:

choices.text: Hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L
Hypernatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium, thereby leading to hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L.

 Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. 

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH include:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria demonstrates tumbling type of motility at 25 °C, but is non-motile at 37 °C?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes demonstrates tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28 °C but becomes non-motile at 37 °C. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. These rods are facultatively intracellular and move from cell to cell using the host cell actin framework. It can grow at low refrigeration temperatures. They show tumbling motility at 25°C. But, at 37°C, it is non-motile because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C.

The image below shows the tumbling motility of L. monocytogenes.

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was on crutches for a few months after a road traffic accident. After the initial 2 weeks, he complained of an inability to extend his wrist. He achieved complete recovery a few weeks later. What is the mechanism behind this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man not able to extend his wrist after the use of a crutch and complete recovery after a few weeks is suggestive of crutch palsy which is a type of neurapraxia. 

Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological block in nerve conduction. Some types of sensation and muscle power are lost in neuropraxia. The structure of the nerve is not changed and there is complete, spontaneous recovery after a few weeks. Neurapraxia occurs due to segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure. 

Crutch palsy occurs when the radial nerve is compressed in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object (crutch). Other examples of neuropraxia include Saturday night palsy and tourniquet palsy.

Other options:

Option A: Neurotmesis occurs due to the damage in both axon and nerve by a complete section or scarring of a segment in open fractures. A surgical nerve repair is required since spontaneous recovery doesn't take place.

Option B: Axonotmesis occurs due to the damage of axons with preservation of the internal architecture of the nerve. It is seen typically after closed fractures and dislocations. Spontaneous recovery can occur but may take a long time.

Option C: Neurolysis is the surgical removal of fibrotic tissue inside a nerve trunk.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis (MG).

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR.

Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal.

A lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. Proctoscopy is done as an OPD procedure to detect hemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers

questions.text: A young man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. The biopsy of the intestine is shown below. His symptoms improved with folic acid intake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with histopathology showing partial villous atrophy with inflammation of lamina propria, and improvement with folic acid intake suggest that the patient has tropical sprue.

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. Patients present with diarrhea, steatorrhoea, weight loss, folic acid, and vitamin B12 deficiency.

The small intestinal mucosal biopsy is diagnostic and reveals partial villous atrophy and mononuclear cell infiltration in the lamina propria. 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics such as tetracycline can be given for 6 months and folic acid is often curative. A gluten-free diet doesn't improve the condition. 

Other options:

Option A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Patients present with iron deficiency anaemia, weight loss, diarrhea, and malabsorption. Biopsy reveals blunting of villi, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation propria. They respond to a gluten-free diet.

The below image shows histopathological findings seen in celiac disease.

Option B- Whipple's disease is a multiorgan disease caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterised by arthralgia, arthritis, weight loss, diarrhea,  abdominal pain, and psychiatric manifestation. The organism can be detected by tissue immunohistochemistry and tissue staining for PAS-positive macrophages.

The below image shows the PAS stain in Whipple's disease.

Option D: Short bowel syndrome occurs after the resection of various lengths of the small intestine. Patients will have diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and micro and macronutrient deficiencies.

questions.text: Parents of a child with febrile seizures are concerned about the relapse, complications, and treatment of this condition. All of the following are true regarding the risks and management of this case, except:

choices.text: Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of a recurrent febrile seizure
Clobazam or clonazepam help reduce recurrence of febrile seizures
Anti-epileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy
Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality increases the risk of febrile seizures

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true, except for option C: Antiepileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy. The risk of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Febrile seizures are seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
 Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy are 6%

Investigations:

  • In first episode of febrile seizure, lumbar puncture is indicated in cases of clinically suspected meningitis.
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

An acute episode of seizure is terminated by intravenous lorazepam or midazolam. Antipyretics and proper hydration.

Prophylaxis:

  • In children with risk factors for recurrence or those with frequent recurrences (≥3 in 6 months or ≥4 in one year),give intermittent prophylaxis for 3 days during the fever episode to reduces recurrences.

Note:

  • Antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but do not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam help reduce but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • The risk of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality increases the risk of febrile seizures.

questions.text: A resident is examining a patient with bilateral leg swelling below the knees. He notes that on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. What is the likely cause of the edema?
questions.solution:
Bilateral non-pitting edema in the lower limbs is suggestive of myxedema.

Pretibial myxedema is a manifestation of Grave's disease. The triad of Grave's disease is orbitopathy, goiter, and pretibial myxedema.

This change is caused due to an increased glycosaminoglycan deposition in the skin giving it an edematous appearance. Despite this appearance, the skin does not pit with pressure.

While chronic lymphangitis and acute lymphatic filariasis can also cause non-pitting edema, they usually have a unilateral/localized presentation. Nephrotic syndrome and heart failure cause bilateral pitting edema.

Causes of generalized edema include:

  • Heart failure
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Liver cirrhosis

Causes of localized edema include:

  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Chronic lymphangitis
  • Resection of regional lymph nodes
  • Filariasis

questions.text: Which of the following is the defective DNA repair mechanism seen in patients with Severe Combined Immuno Deficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ).

Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) is a mechanism by which a group of proteins mediates the recognition, processing, and direct ligation of the ends of two DNA fragments where a double-strand break in DNA has occurred. This is in contrast to homologous repair (HR), another mechanism, where an undamaged homologous DNA template is required to replace an adjacent damaged one.

NHEJ deficiency confers combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, etc.
  • The most common form is X-linked SCID, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • other gene mutations that can be seen in SCID are JAK3, RAG1, IL-7R, etc.

questions.text: Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses _____ as its secondary messenger.
questions.solution:
Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses cAMP as its secondary messenger.

Vasopressin is a nonapeptide hormone that is synthesized in the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary. Vasopressin plays a vital role in controlling the body's osmotic balance, blood pressure regulation, and sodium homeostasis.

Vasopressin acts on

  • V1 receptor to cause vasoconstriction using calcium as its secondary messenger.
  • V2 receptor to facilitate reabsorption of water through aquaporin 2, primarily in the collecting ducts, using cAMP as its secondary messenger.
  • Thus, vasopressin acts on g-protein coupled receptors using different secondary messengers to accomplish its various actions.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. His erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal X-ray shows left staghorn renal calculi. The best treatment option for staghorn renal calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Staghorn calculi is also known as triple phosphate stone. It occupies the renal pelvis and calyces.

PCNL: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pulviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Stones not responding for ESWL

Other options:

Option A: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option C: Percutaneous nephrostomy, or nephropyelostomy, is an interventional procedure that is used in the decompression of the renal collecting system.

It is done in grossly unwell patients due to sepsis secondary to an obstructive urinary tract calculi. They drain pus from the kidneys adequately with less manipulation and a lower risk of septicemia than a ureteric stent.

Option D: Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: The given emblem shows an organization related to which organism?
questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP). Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

Characteristics of NLEP emblem:

  • The lotus in the NLEP emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb, a normal forefinger, and the shape of a house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and that a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of leprosy.

NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Other options:

Option A- Programme dealing with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, is National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP)

Option C and D - Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis and Leishmania donovani causes Kala-azar, which are vector-borne diseases. National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

Sigmoid volvulus is a condition that occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.

A sigmoid volvulus can be differentiated from a cecal volvulus by swirl sign, location of the obstructed loop, and anatomical appendages. The swirl with sigmoid volvulus is located on the right quadrant while the swirl with cecal volvulus is located at the pelvic brim. 

Other options:

Option B: Colonic diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. The barium enema given below shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth. 

Option C: Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. 

Option D: Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure. This leads to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. The image given below is an X-ray of a patient with a paralytic ileus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is indicated in the management of hyperthyroidism.

Other options

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers are fetopathic and can cause fetal growth retardation and hypoplasia of organs. 

Statins can cause Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects

questions.text: Which is the shortest acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (succinylcholine) is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant.

It has a rapid-onset (30–60secs) and short duration of action (typically less than 10 min) due to rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase).

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing & non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant: 

  • Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant:

Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes)

  • Gantacurium

Short-acting (10-20 minutes)

  • Mivacurium

 Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

  • Atracurium
  • Cisatracurium
  • Vecuronium
  • Rocuronium

Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Pancuronium
  • Doxacurium

questions.text: A woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

Sheehan syndrome also called post-partum pituitary necrosis refers to the necrosis of the pituitary gland following significant post-partum bleeding, hypovolemia, and shock. It may present acutely as an endocrine emergency or present chronically.The late presentation has the following features:

  • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

Option B: Hyperthyroidism can cause oligomenorrhoea and amenorrhea but is likely to have symptoms of hyperthyroidism like weight loss, palpitations, tremors, heat intolerance, dyspnea on exertion, diarrhoea and muscle weakness.

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Pituitary apoplexy is a condition in which there is a haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. This disorder commonly occurs in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma. This patient does not have any signs of adenoma and a history of PPH makes Sheehan syndrome more likely.

questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the image given below, all of the following can be found in the area marked 'x' except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises 1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with 16 weeks of gestation presents with cramping abdominal pain followed by the passage of fleshy mass per vaginum. The pain subsided following the expulsion. On examination, the uterus appeared smaller with the os closed and the bleeding had stopped. Ultrasound reveals an empty uterine cavity. This is a case of ____________ miscarriage.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of complete miscarriage.

Expulsion of products of conception, en masse, is called a complete miscarriage.

Features:

  • Subsidence of abdominal pain
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus is smaller
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • USG - empty uterine cavity

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A: In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • The uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Well-formed gestation ring
  • Fetal cardiac motion
  • Blighted ovum

Option C: In inevitable miscarriage, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

Option D: In missed miscarriage, the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period

Features: The patient usually presents with features of threatened miscarriage followed by

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • Cessation of uterine growth
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac

In incomplete miscarriage, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity

  • Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • Patulous cervical os
  • Echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity

In septic abortion, there will be clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents

Features:

  • Rise of the temperature of at least 100.4 F for 24 hours or more
  • Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge
  • Other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness.
